Award.AwardTitle: Investigations of multi-phase chemistry in levitated surrogate cloud droplets
Award.AbstractNarration: The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor Frank N. Keutsch at the University of Wisconsin- Madison who proposes a novel experimental approach that will simulate cloud-processing of reactive hydrocarbons, which is an important pathway for the formation and transformation of ambient fine particulate matter (aerosol). Cloud processing influences aerosol concentrations and physicochemical properties, which in turn regulate aerosol optical and cloud-nucleating properties. Cloud processing thus represents a paradigm for chemistry-climate coupling. The proposed approach combines optical tweezers with a suite of analytical instrumentation to transcend existing experimental limitations, allowing exploration of the critical competition of gas/condensed phase exchange, chemical reactions and cloud droplet drying/growth cycles. The research will provide important mechanistic parameters of aerosol formation and properties, which are currently lacking in models of climate and air quality. The proposed work is ultimately designed to aid prediction of aerosol properties, thereby enhancing the mitigation of anthropogenic effects on human health, the environment and the climate. This project will also provide education of scientists and develop undergraduate laboratory experiments that consider not only individual processes, but also the coupled chemical/physical feedbacks, such as those between the gas and condensed phases. The work will also expand the scope of analytical experimental methodology available to other fields of research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Suspended aerosol particles represent an important component of the atmosphere. The presence of particles, particularly those of diameter less than 2.5 micron (PM2.5), has been shown to have a deleterious effect on human health and they also play a key role in the Earth's climate system. An accurate representation of aerosol particles across the entire range of atmospheric conditions requires a complete understanding of the chemical and physical processes that transform particles. These processes can include wetting and drying cycles as a particle encounters parcels of air with varying relative humidity. Particles can gain or lose mass as compounds partition between the gas and condensed phase, depending on their volatility. Furthermore, the chemical components of the aerosol particle can change due to chemical reactions that take place either wholly within the particle or heterogeneously, at the interface between gas and condensed phases. Adding further complexity to this chemical system, these processes can be modulated by physical properties of the particle, such as high viscosity leading to diffusion limitations, or phase separation leading to the partitioning of the particle's components between an organic-rich and a water-rich phase.

One of the challenges has been the ability to investigate these processes, which determine the fate and properties of particles, over atmospherically relevant time scales of many days, primarily as particles in most experimental approaches do not live that long. Experimental approaches that trap individual particles overcome this challenge and enable measurements of aerosol particles in a highly controlled environment. The trapping force can be maintained by an optical, acoustic or electric field. The particle can be generated with a precisely known composition and the particle only makes contact with the surrounding gas phase, whose composition can also be controlled. In this way, different aspects of the complex physicochemical system detailed in the previous paragraph can be isolated and studied.

However, this approach had previously been mainly confined to studying the evolution of physical properties of particles, such as size or optical properties.

Coupling these trapping experiments with mass spectrometric detection enables investigation of the evolution of the chemical composition of particles over atmospherically relevant timescales but this approach had primarily been limited to large acoustically-trapped droplets.

Under this grant we developed a method that enables mass spectrometric detection of the evolution of the chemical composition of much smaller trapped droplets/particles. We investigated acoustic traps, optical tweezers and Bessel beam traps, as well as electrodynamic balances, i.e., using electric fields to trap particles. We furthermore explored a large number of different ionization methods to determine optimal mass spectrometric detection. Using the acoustic trap approach we were successfully able to conduct kinetic experiments, studying the rate of a reaction and its dependence on drying of large particles. Our work showed that electrodynamic balances are most suitable for coupling small trapped particles to mass-spectrometric detection. This approach is highly efficient with near unity probability of both capturing particles and transferring them to mass-spectrometric detection. With this approach we were able to follow the evolution of droplets, which enables observation of the partitioning rates of individual components of a mixture of chemicals. This novel approach is ground-breaking and will allow detailed testing and improvement of models of gas-particle partitioning, especially for non-ideal systems as well as how chemical reactions in the particle phase can influence the volatility of particles. This approach will therefore help our understanding of the atmospheric fate and properties of particles, which is of high relevance to climate and human health.
